It is located about 95 km north of
in the hilly area near the

mountains on the Teleajen river valley. Vălenii de Munte was first documented in the XV-th century. It was known as a market town in the early years, mainly because it's proximity to the Walachia - Transilvania border greatly developed trade in the area. Several constructions from that time still stand and are visitable, including the "Mănăstirea" church, dated 1680, and the "Sf. Nicolae Tabaci" church.
(30-40 minutes travel time, and very frequent) and several daily buses from Bucharest (two hours travel time); some of their schedules are available on
Although it has a railway connection to
, it is currently unavailable. Several options are being considered to reopen travel by train in the area.
The town can be visited on foot. It has a length of about 5km, and the central area where most of the objectives are located is less than 2,5km

value: content=It was the home of the romanian historian Nicolae Iorga. His coming to Vălenii de Munte transformed the town into an academic and cultural center.

Accommodations are available in several guesthouses with prices starting around €12/night.
